Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  builds  on  achievements  under  a  previous  TA  which 
introduced managing for development results (MfDR) principles to investment planning, and 
developed  options  for  improved  public  funds  management.1 The  earlier  MfDR  TA  was 
successful in demonstrating how public investment planning and monitoring can be linked with 
strategic sector objectives, and piloted the approach in key sectors.  
 
2.  The Government of Mongolia has requested further assistance in applying MfDR in 
national  planning,  investment  planning  in  selected  line  ministries,  and  related  capacity 
development. The goal of the proposed TA is to contribute to a stronger results orientation in 
national development planning and implementation processes, and to better management of 
public resources. The proposed TA is included in the Mongolia country operations business plan, 
2009–2012.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The proposed TA will support integration of MfDR in the public sector management cycle 
(i.e.  planning,  budgeting,  monitoring  and  evaluation),  strengthen  the  results  orientation  in 
national development planning and implementation processes, and improve the management of 
public resources.  
 
4.  The government is a signatory to the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness. It has 
formed  seven  technical  working  groups  to  foster  harmonization,  and  has  established  the 
National Development and Innovation Committee (NDIC) which reports to the Prime Minister 
and is responsible for strengthening prioritization and improving the effectiveness of public 
investments. While the Ministry of Finance has retained its oversight responsibilities for public 
sector financing, the NDIC is playing an increasing role in public investment planning.  
 
5.  The previous MfDR TA has been at the center of the government and ADB's sector 
strategy  work  aimed  at  mainstreaming  the  MfDR  approach  in  investment  planning  and 
measurement of development outcomes. It has supported assessments of performance based 
monitoring  systems  in  the  urban  and  education  sectors,  development  of  sector-specific 
investment  roadmaps,  and  mechanisms  for  improved  targeting  of  social  expenditures. 
Assistance under the TA has been timely in light of the fiscal impact of the global financial crisis, 
and has achieved strengthened capacity development through ongoing engagement of the 
Ministry of Finance and line ministries in dialogue on investment planning. 
 
6.  Establishment of the NDIC in December 2008 was an important step toward integrating 
MfDR principles into national processes for planning, budgeting, monitoring and evaluation of 
public investments, and the new agency is making steady progress. In its first 18 months, NDIC 
has  (i)  developed  a  draft  medium-term  development  strategy,  2010–2015  Development 
Priorities, together with a medium-term investment plan, Midterm Development Priorities; (ii) 
prepared an annual development plan, Socio Economic Development Guidelines, that is based 
on the medium-term development strategy; (iii) developed a socioeconomic development index 
to monitor progress on the medium-term development strategy; (iv) prepared a database to 
collect and organize data on public investment from government agencies, and a survey to

collect data on private investment; and (v) prepared a draft law on planning in collaboration with 
the Ministry of Finance to ensure compatibility with the draft budget law, which is also expected 
to be considered by Parliament in 2010. 
 
7.  Additional work is needed to turn these plans and processes into a successful public 
investment  planning  process,  particularly  in  an  environment  in  which  a  greater  range  of 
financing options are being considered by the government. Currently, projects are taken directly 
to the cabinet for approval without screening them to ensure consistency with the National 
Development Strategy (NDS). The public investment program focuses on domestically-financed 
projects,  and  foreign-funded  projects  are  planned  and  presented  outside  this  framework. 
Mongolia's budget classification system generally complies with international norms and the 
annual government budget document discusses progress made in the projects, although without 
discussing their strategic rationale, consistency with the domestic public investment program, 
and overall prioritization. While line ministries undertake strategic planning exercises, these are 
not effectively costed, adequately scrutinized, or coordinated with the government’s overall 
priorities.  
 
8.  The effectiveness of assistance from Mongolia's development partners is inextricably 
linked  with  the  application  of  MfDR  principles  to  national  investment  planning  and  public 
expenditure management. A joint review of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World 
Bank  portfolios  in  Mongolia  in  2009  revealed  a  common  set  of  priority  issues.  However, 
investments are slow to start up because of a lack of readiness at project inception, which 
delays benefits and increases administrative costs. Procurement delays are pervasive due to 
weak  capacity  and  an  excessive  number  of  small  contracts.  Frameworks  for  monitoring 
investment performance are mostly focused on inputs and outputs rather than on impacts and 
outcomes. Addressing these shortcomings will help to link investments with national priorities 
and deliver more effective and relevant outcomes.   
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  impact  of  the  proposed  TA  will  be  results-based  public  investment  planning, 
implementation,  and  monitoring  at  the  national  level.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  the 
application of MfDR principles in planning and management by the Ministry of Finance, NDIC 
and line ministries and agencies concerned. The TA will: (i) develop sector-specific results 
framework in priority sectors; (ii) improve the results focus in project design, implementation, 
monitoring, and evaluation; (iii) strengthen results-based public sector financial management; (iv) 
link public sector investment planning to the NDS and to a multi-year budget; (v) improve 
integrity  and  accountability  in  the  management  of  public  resources;  (vi)  strengthen  aid 
coordination,  harmonization,  and  effectiveness;  (vii)  develop  risk  assessments;  and  (viii) 
improve the MfDR capacities of the Ministry of Finance, NDIC, the State Property Committee 
and selected line ministries. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The  proposed  TA  has  three  components:  (i)  mainstreaming  MfDR  in  public  sector 
management;  (ii)  improved  results-based  delivery  and  coordination  of  official  development 
assistance  to  Mongolia;  and  (iii)  institutional  and  human  capacity  building  through  advice, 
analytical support and training.

3 
11.  The first component will help the government to mainstream key principles of MfDR, 
including  a  results  focus  throughout  the  public  sector  management  cycle,  and  strengthen 
evidence-based policy and program decision making based on a clear framework for results, 
monitoring and evaluation. Key outputs will include: (i) application of MfDR principles in planning, 
budgeting, monitoring and evaluation; (ii) completion of sector risk assessments and action 
plans  in  four  sectors;  and  (iii)  strengthened  capacity  in  Ministry  of  Finance  and  four  line 
agencies in audit, procurement and anticorruption measures. Activities will focus on clarifying 
the delineation of roles and mandates among government institutions for improving results 
orientation  in  national  development  planning,  implementation,  procurement,  monitoring  and 
coordination; and establishing stronger links between national plans and strategies by devising 
results frameworks and guidelines for relevant ministries and government agencies.  
 
12.  The  second  component  will  help  to  strengthen  the  government's  role  in  improving 
efficiency and effectiveness of official development assistance to ensure strong links with the 
NDS and results delivery. Key outputs will include establishment of coordination, communication 
and  reporting  systems  across  institutions  for  effective  integration,  programming,  and 
implementation  of  national  development  strategies;  and  increased  public  awareness, 
transparency, and capacity in public procurement. Activities include (i) assisting the government 
to  formulate  sector-wide  assistance  approaches  in  priority  areas  of  ADB  assistance;  (ii) 
assisting  the  government  to  identify  its  aid  needs  and  to  coordinate  and  co-lead  donor 
harmonization  efforts,  especially  in  priority  areas  of  ADB  intervention;  (iii)  engaging  with 
executing agencies to improve ADB portfolio performance, particularly in procurement and at 
project  start-up;  and  (iv)  engaging  other  development  partners  and  local  nongovernment 
organizations in assessing, monitoring, and reviewing the development effectiveness of external 
assistance,  including  joint  efforts  toward  improved  procurement  processes,  practices,  and 
outcomes. 
 
13.  The  third  component  will  continue  to  develop  institutional  capacity  by  following  up 
activities initiated during the previous TA. The components will support the following outputs: (i) 
addressing knowledge gaps through advisory services, analytical work and other knowledge 
services  including  policy  briefs;  (ii)  improved  human  capacity  in  MfDR  approaches  by 
conducting joint workshops and conferences that promote MfDR principles. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $2,120,000 equivalent. The government has 
requested ADB to finance $1,800,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s technical assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will finance the balance of 
the  cost,  equivalent  to  $320,000,  through  the  provision  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space, 
workshop  venues,  and  other  in-kind  contributions (see  Appendix  2  for  details  of  the  cost 
estimates and financing plan).  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA,  which  will  be 
implemented over 2.5 years from 14 September 2010 to 28 February 2013. The government will 
form a steering committee that will be chaired by the Ministry of Finance and will comprise 
representatives of the Ministry of Finance and NDIC. The Ministry of Finance will be the direct 
government counterpart for the proposed TA and will be responsible for coordinating activities. 
The Ministry of Finance will assign a vice-minister or state secretary as project director, who will 
coordinate overall implementation of the proposed TA within the Ministry of Finance and with

4 
NDIC and line ministries. A department within the Ministry of Finance will be designated to 
assist the project director with day-to-day implementation, and with coordinating with ADB and 
TA consultants. 
 
16.  The total consultants’ input is estimated at 35 person-months of international and 82 
person-months of national consulting services. The consultants will be engaged as individuals in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  The  international  consultants  will  include  public  sector  financial  management  and 
monitoring specialists (6 person-months), sector specialists (20 person-months), public financial 
sector specialist (6 person-months), and procurement experts (3 person-months). The national 
consultants will include a project coordinator (18 person-months), monitoring and evaluation 
experts  (14  person-months),  sector  experts  (22  person-months),  capital  market  expert  (4 
person-months), training specialists (12 person-months), and procurement experts (12 person-
months). The terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
17.  Since consulting services will cover a broad range of areas and sectors, some of which 
are to be determined during project implementation, and considering that most assignments will 
be small and on an intermittent basis, hiring individual consultants is considered appropriate. 
The government will provide the TA consultants with a suitably furnished office with utilities, 
telecommunication access, materials, maps, data and all related documents required by the TA. 
Costs associated with training programs, workshops and conferences will be administered by 
individual consultants. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
18.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $1,800,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Mongolia for 
Managing for Development Results.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   A total of 35 person-months of international and 82 person-months of national consulting 
services are required for the proposed technical assistance (TA).  
 
2.   Given the complexity of public sector financial management and the evolving nature of 
techniques to monitor managing for development results (MfDR), the terms of reference for 
specific tasks may be revised or supplemented in consultation with the government. 
 
A.  Public  Sector  Financial  Management  and  Monitoring  Specialist  (international, 6 
person-months on an intermittent basis)
 
 
3.   The  specialist  will  help  the  Ministry  of  Finance  develop and  enhance  public  sector 
financial  management  under  the  MfDR-based  public  investment  planning  and  monitoring 
system, and will conduct training workshops for national consultants and government officials. 
The specialist must have a strong background and expertise in transition economies, and 
working experience in public sector financial management, procurement, investment planning, 
and monitoring. Experience with MfDR approaches is desirable. He or she will work closely with 
government counterparts to ensure capacity enhancement in the areas of procurement, project 
implementation and administration. Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Systematically assess the existing framework, policies, and procedures on results 
management  in  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  focusing  on  (a)  links  between  plans, 
budgets,  and  action;  (b)  institutional  structure;  (c)  clarity  of  objectives  and 
performance  standards;  (d)  feedback  to  decision-making  mechanisms;  
(e)  performance  accountability  systems;  and  (f)  commitment,  leadership,  and 
ownership  to  apply  MfDR  approaches.  As  part  of  this  process,  undertake 
diagnostic risk assessments in priority sectors. 
(ii)   Coordinate with MfDR-related initiatives in the government to identify indicators 
and benchmarks that can be used in a results management system. 
(iii)   Design a comprehensive results management system for public sector financial 
management and monitoring, including the main directions and guiding principles 
for  MfDR-based  investment  planning;  the  major  results-based  approaches  to 
planning,  budgeting,  and  implementation;  a  set  of  realistic  and  measurable 
indicators for monitoring and evaluating public sector financial management in 
Mongolia; systems to monitor them; related enhancement or adjustment of the 
institutional setup as appropriate; and processes for feedback and use of the 
monitoring information for learning and decision making. 
(iv)   Develop and enhance the management and implementation plan for applying the 
MfDR system, and a mechanism for refining various elements of the system. 
(v)   Produce  MfDR  methodology  papers  and  guidelines  for  use  by  the  Ministry  of 
Finance and line ministries, including guidance on the further development of the 
government's e-procurement system, where appropriate. 
(vi)   Devise a training program, with capacity-building and communications tools, based 
on a needs assessment, and conduct training workshops for government officials, 
key stakeholders, government control institutions and future trainers.  
(vii)   Support the establishment of a community of practice for MfDR in Mongolia and 
help strengthen its operations.

10 Appendix 3 
 
B.  Sector Specialists (international, 20 person-months on an intermittent basis)
 
 
4.   A total of 20 person-months of international consulting services will be engaged to 
support the design and application of MfDR to line ministries and agencies concerned. The 
sector specialists may also be commissioned to provide MfDR-related advisory services and/or 
undertake assessments and other analytical work. They will work closely with government 
counterparts. They should have at least a master's degree or equivalent in a relevant field, and 
at least 5 years' relevant experience. Specific tasks include:  
(i)   Assist selected line ministries with the design and application of a tailor-made 
MfDR system along the lines of the Ministry of Finance’s MfDR framework, to 
identify, formulate, implement, and monitor public sector financial management, 
and other investment projects. 
(ii)   Provide advisory services, analysis, and assessments as appropriate, which will (a) 
guide  public  sector  financial  management,  (b)  fill  knowledge  gaps  in  project 
identification and design, (c) explore innovative investment approaches such as 
public–private  partnerships,  (d)  update  information  and  analysis  required  for 
aligning public sector financial management to MfDR objectives, and (e) assess 
the need for related requirements of information and communication technology. 
(iii)   Produce  MfDR  methodology  papers,  and  guidelines  for  use  by  line  ministries 
concerned. 
(iv)   Devise a training program based on a needs assessment and conduct training 
workshops for government officials and future trainers in the Ministry of Finance 
and line ministries/agencies concerned. 
 
C.  Public Financial Sector Specialist (international, 6 person-months on an intermittent 
basis)
 
 
5.   The specialist should have experience in financial sector management. He or she will 
work  closely  with  teams  enhancing  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  financial 
management. The specialist will work closely with government counterparts to ensure capacity 
enhancement. He or she should have at least a master's degree or equivalent in a relevant field, 
and at least 5 years' relevant experience.  Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Improve and enhance the management of the government’s public funds, providing 
a  comprehensive  analysis  of  options  such  as  in-house  management  versus 
contracting, and recommendations on the optimal interface with the government. 
(ii)   Review  the  mandate,  structure,  corporate  governance,  functions,  and 
measurement and monitoring systems of the agency charged with managing the 
government’s public funds, in line with international best practice. 
(iii)   Review results-based financial management strategies to ensure the match of 
assets and liabilities management with risk management requirements. 
(iv)   Improve  and  enhance  operational  business  plans  for  financial  management 
including capacity development and systems development, internal controls, and 
monitoring. 
(v)   Devise a training program based on a needs assessment and conduct training 
workshops for government officials and future trainers. 
(vi)  Hold workshops to discuss proposals that are developed, so that government and 
private  sector  stakeholders  are  given  a  clear  message  about  what  is  being 
proposed, and how it could be implemented. 
(vii)   Assess capital markets, focusing on constraints to entry and operations of public 
funds in the capital markets, and make proposals to address such constraints, 
particularly through a long-term bond market and stock exchange.

Appendix 3 11
 
D.  Procurement Experts (international, 3 person-months on an intermittent basis; national, 
12 person-months on an intermittent basis) 
 
6.  International and national procurement experts will be engaged during the course of the 
TA to support the Ministry of Finance to implement its action plan for public procurement 
reforms in Mongolia, covering capacity building, transparency, public awareness, civil society 
participation,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  related  issues.    Each  expert  should  hold  a 
postgraduate degree in a relevant discipline, and have at least 5 years' experience in public 
procurement, specifically in implementation of development projects, procurement reviews and 
audits, capacity building, e-procurement, country procurement assessments, and/or national 
procurement reform programs. Specific tasks include: 
(i)  Provide  advice,  analysis,  and  assessments,  as  appropriate,  for:  (a)  the 
establishment of an accreditation and monitoring system for training institutes 
with a quality control mechanism; and (b) enhanced transparency measures, 
such as the further development of Mongolia's e-procurement platform. 
(ii)  Develop public awareness tools, such as briefings or pamphlets on key aspects 
of the procurement law, orientation workshops and infomercials. 
(iii)  Develop user's guides and checklists to assist third-party observers identify key 
steps in a public procurement process and indicators of corruption. 
(iv)  Create a training program for other stakeholders in public procurement, such as 
the private sector, civil society organizations, government procurement control 
institutions, the media, and possibly state prosecutors and judges. 
(v)  Review, update and improve the training curriculum, materials and other capacity 
building tools (such as manuals, standard bidding documents and handbooks) for 
procurement practitioners in the government. 
(vi)  Develop a procurement audit manual and a procurement monitoring tool for 
government procurement control institutions, the Ministry of Finance and internal 
auditors. 
 
E.  Project Coordinator (national, 18 person-months)
 
 
7.   The project coordinator will have a good knowledge of MfDR, leadership and managerial 
skills, expertise in capacity development, and extensive experience in dealing with government 
agencies, funding agency communities, and public and private sectors. The coordinator will lead 
other national consultants in providing support as appropriate to international consultants and 
closely coordinate with the Ministry of Finance as the executing agency. He or she should have 
at least a master's degree or equivalent in a relevant field, and at least 5 years' relevant 
experience. Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Be the focal point for the TA and liaise with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and the Ministry of Finance on issues related to TA implementation. 
(ii)   Supervise and act as leader to the team of national consultants. 
(iii)   Coordinate with the Ministry of Finance and ADB on pilot testing in line ministries 
and agencies. 
(iv)   Coordinate with the Ministry of Finance and ADB on expansion of MfDR to other 
line ministries. 
(v)   Ensure effective coordination between government agencies and aid agencies, 
and avoid overlapping of the TA with work undertaken by other aid agencies. 
(vi)   Assist the international consultants in developing the MfDR systems in the Ministry 
of Finance and line ministries.

12 Appendix 3 
 
(vii)   Organize  consultations  with  other  stakeholders  over  Mongolia’s  community  of 
practice for MfDR. 
(viii)  Organize  workshops,  training,  seminars  and  conferences  based  on  a  needs 
assessment and in consultation with the Ministry of Finance, line ministries and 
international consultants, and with the support of other national consultants. 
(ix)   Arrange for translation and publication of MfDR guidelines and other assessment 
and analytical work in consultation with ADB, the Ministry of Finance and/or line 
ministries,  and  the  international  consultants  concerned;  develop  a  website  on 
which training and other project materials can be uploaded for ease of access, 
updated and easily available to all relevant staff. 
(x)   Report to ADB on progress and achievements in implementing the TA. 
 
F.  Monitoring and Evaluation Experts (national, 14 person-months, on an intermittent 
basis)
 
 
8.   The consultants will have expertise in developing and implementing MfDR systems, and 
a  background  and  extensive  working  experience  in  public  sector  financial  management, 
investment planning, and monitoring, impact assessment, and data analysis and interpretation. 
They should have at least a university degree in a relevant field, and at least 5 years' relevant 
experience.  Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Collect  data  and  provide  background  on  the  existing  framework,  institutions, 
policies, procedures, and legislation on results management in the Ministry of 
Finance and line ministries concerned. 
(ii)   Assist the international results-based financial sector and monitoring specialist and 
sector  specialists  or  economists  in  developing  an  MfDR-based  public  sector 
financial management, procurement, investment planning and monitoring system in 
the Ministry of Finance and other line ministries. 
(iii)   Assist with pilot testing and training for implementing the MfDR. 
(iv)   Assist  in  preparing  MfDR  methodology  papers,  and  guidelines  for  use  by  the 
Ministry of Finance and line ministries concerned, and ensure proper publication 
and dissemination in local languages. 
(v)   Assist with the workshops, training, seminars, and conferences for the relevant 
MfDR systems. 
 
G.  Sector Experts (national, 22 person-months on an intermittent basis)
 
 
9.   National consultants will be engaged for 22 person-months to support the international 
consultants in MfDR-related advisory services, assessments, and analytical work. They will 
have a strong background and extensive working experience in the sectors concerned. They 
should have at least a master's degree or equivalent in a relevant field, and at least 5 years' 
relevant experience.   Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Collect data and provide background on the sectors concerned, including existing 
institutions, policies, and legislation on the sectors; past development and future 
prospects;  special  characteristics  of  the  sectors;  and  major  constraints  and 
opportunities for the sectors. 
(ii)   Help the international sector specialists to provide MfDR-related advisory services 
and/or undertaking assessments and other analytical work. 
(iii)   Ensure proper publication and dissemination of the analytical work in Mongolian.  
(iv)   Assist with the workshops, training, seminars, and conferences for the relevant 
advisory services, assessments and analytical work.

Appendix 3 13
H.  Capital Market Expert (national, 4 person-months on an intermittent basis)
 
 
10.   The expert will support the public sector financial specialist in developing further public 
or social funds management strategies, structure, and systems; and addressing the constraints 
identified and adequate operations of public or social funds in the capital markets. He or she 
should have at least a master's degree or equivalent in a relevant field, and at least 5 years' 
relevant experience.  Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Collect data and provide background on public financial management and capital 
markets. 
(ii)   Assist the financial sector specialist in (a) improving and enhancing the structure of 
the management of the government’s public funds; (b) reviewing the mandate, 
structure,  corporate  governance,  functions,  monitoring  mechanism  and 
measurement systems of the agency charged with managing the government’s 
public funds; (c) improving the results-based financial management strategy to 
match assets and liabilities management and risk management requirements; and 
(d) further developing operational business plans for financial management. 
(iii)   Assist  the  public  sector  financial  specialist  in  assessing  the  capital  markets, 
focusing on constraints to entry and adequate operations of public funds in the 
capital  markets,  and  giving  concrete  proposals  to  address  those  constraints, 
particularly by developing a long-term bonds market and stock exchange. 
(iv)   Assist the public sector financial specialist in devising a training program and 
conducting training workshops to achieve the required skills complement. 
(v)   Assist  with  preparing  training  materials,  and  ensure  proper  publication  and 
dissemination. 
 
I.  Training Specialist (national, 12 person-months on an intermittent basis)
 
 
11.   The specialist will have experience in arranging and conducting workshops and training 
programs. He or she should have at least a university degree in a relevant field and at least 5 
years' relevant experience. Based on the training plan to be developed by the international 
results-based  public  sector  financial  management  and  monitoring  specialist  and  sector 
specialists, and in close coordination with the Ministry of Finance, line ministries, and the project 
coordinator, the training specialist will be responsible for implementing the planned training 
events under the TA. Specific tasks include: 
(i)   Deliver to ADB and the Ministry of Finance within 2 months of the beginning of the 
contract a report on the proposed methodology for selecting the participants and 
determining the topics for capacity-building events, including criteria, processes 
and procedures, together with a set of user-friendly forms, questionnaires and 
other relevant tools. 
(ii)   Develop a measurement mechanism to collect and analyze feedback from both the 
trainer and trainees on training events, which will be used to further improve the 
conduct of subsequent training and capacity development programs. 
(iii)   Design the training programs in consultation with the Ministry of Finance or line 
ministries and international consultants. 
(iv)   Procure and set up the equipment and software for training purposes. 
(v)   Prepare  course  materials,  manuals  and  other  communications  tools,  such  as 
user's guides or pamphlets and checklists, in consultation with the EA or line 
ministries and international or national consultants concerned. 
(vi)   Provide logistical support for the training. 
(vii)   Provide technical inputs to the training events, when requested.

14 Appendix 3 
 
(viii)  Prepare and submit to ADB and the Ministry of Finance within 1 week of each 
training event a summary note that depicts the program and proceedings of the 
training and summarizes major achievements and feedback. 
 
J.   Reporting Arrangements 
 
12.   All consultants will report to the Mongolia Resident Mission project officer and the project 
coordinator, and work closely with the Ministry of Finance. Each international consultant will 
submit  to  ADB  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  an  inception  report  within  2  weeks  after  the 
beginning of the contract, and a final report within 1 week after the contractual period ends. If 
the national consultants need to prepare any analytical report,that requirement will be specified 
 
in  the  terms  of  reference  of  the  engagement  contract.  All  reports  will  be  in  English;  any 
requirement to translate reports into Mongolian will be specified in consultants' detailed terms of 
reference.
